org_name: San Luis Valley Health Regional Medical Center

request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release Medical Record Information (2024 update)
Mail to SLV Health-RMC (106 Blanca Ave, Alamosa, CO 81101)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic authorization-to-release form, prints and fills it out by hand listing themselves as the recipient, then emails or mails it to the HIM department.

red_flags: SSN collection as standard field — unnecessary for ROI and creates identity theft risk
Vague disclaimer 'San Luis Valley Health is not responsible if lost' with no context
Persistent spelling error 'INFORMATION REQUIRIED' across multiple form revisions
bright_spots: Spanish-language form co-located with English version on Medical Records page — serves San Luis Valley's Latino community
Email submission accepted at MRChartPullRequest@slvrmc.org — avoids fax-only or in-person-only barriers
Single-page form with granular record-type scope options

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available — form is directly linked from the Medical Records page and immediately found via web search with no barriers.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds — no fillable fields require printing and handwriting, but email submission (MRChartPullRequest@slvrmc.org) provides an electronic submission path after scanning the completed form.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but has notable problems — single-page layout is well-organized, but form lacks instructions, uses moderately legalistic language, includes a confusing copies clause, and contains a persistent spelling error.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — generic third-party release form with no dedicated patient self-access pathway; patient must list themselves as recipient in the 'RELEASE TO' field.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — collects SSN (not required for patient access), provides no rights information or HIPAA references, no fee transparency, and vague 'not responsible if lost' disclaimer.

overall.summary: SLV Health-RMC scores well on findability and offers bilingual support with email submission, but is held back by a generic third-party release form with no fillable fields, no patient-specific pathway, SSN collection, and absent rights information.
